en_second_half: he felt he had said something quite wonderful. But he knew his mouth had only moved to say hello, and then when she seemed hypnotized by the salamander on his arm and the phoenix-disc on his chest, he spoke again.
en_results_raw: Montag felt his flesh jump and had the absurd thought that the girl's eyes were cameras hidden away behind all that black hair, sending off unseizable pictures of him, in burst of light, to be developed in some lab in the middle of the night. He looked away. "Well," he said, "it's not my problem." He felt her dark gaze still upon him and turned to see if that was so. She had gone. He stared after her a moment and then shifted his eyes to the sidewalk where her footprints in the dust were a promise that she had been there and perhaps would be there again, though no foot was in sight now. He looked back up at the beetle-colored sky and the falling drizzle of the special rain. He felt his hands, the kerosene nozzle in one of them, the igniter in the other. He felt his hands and thought, if you had a microscope to look at them closely you would see little ridges of pressure, little peaks of skin piled one on top of the other, in the faintest but irrefutable pattern, like aspens pressed together, the final and irrevocable design of a life formed by pressure on a sensitive skin that mapped out a way of going. And now, how suddenly, this girl who was so nervous, so jumpy, had gone and changed everything with a few words and a strange look. He felt his hands. He felt his arms. He felt his legs. He felt his mind. He felt his whole being flood with a terrible anger against the girl. Why wasn't she like the others? Why wasn't she normal? Why did she have to be like this? Why wasn't she like the ladies at the fire station? Well, hell! He couldn't stop here and think of her, think of her and how she made him feel. He couldn't stand still. He shook the nozzle in the air, his hands dancing above the river of kerosene. He felt the need to run, to race, to sweep her up in his arms and fly with her over the sleeping city, away from the fire, away from the falling night, away, anywhere, everywhere! He stood there, his boots melting little holes in the concrete, his hands trying to freeze each other, his face sunburned, his mind numbed with the effort of trying to understand what was happening to him. He felt his mouth dry and his throat choked with the kerosene fumes; he felt the need to plunge the burning fag-end of a cigarette into his own arm, to feel something, anything, to stop the silent, implacable sobbing of his heart. He looked up at the buildings around him and let the flood of their bright, luminous details drown his perception of everything else. He felt his hands go numb and drop the nozzle. He heard a hiss as the kerosene gushed over the pavement. He saw the blue and red neon signs across the street swim into his eyes. He heard a voice crying out, a voice that seemed to come from the sky, from the earth, from all things that lived and grew. The voice cried: "Montag, you idiot, you almost had it! Why did you stop?" He opened his eyes wide and looked around. The hissing was still in his ears. The pavement was still pouring the dark, familiar river of kerosene. The sun was still bright and high. The girl was still gone. The silence about him was complete. He felt his mouth move and heard a voice, small and thin, but desperately crying out the single word: "Millie!"

La noche había comenzado con un error, pero podría ser el comienzo de una revelación profunda, una prueba que cada uno de ellos tendría que enfrentar para descubrir su verdadera esencia y destino.

Montag watched as the fire consumed the books, the walls, the furniture, everything that had once been part of Mildred's world. The heat was intense, a physical force that pressed against him, threatening to consume him as well. Yet, he stood his ground, a silent observer to the destruction he had set in motion. The fire crackled and hissed, a symphony of chaos that drowned out the sirens of the approaching Mechanical Hound and the distant wail of fire engines. In this moment, Montag felt a strange sense of liberation, as if by burning these books, he was freeing himself from the oppressive weight of ignorance and conformity that had shackled him for so long. The fire raged on, a beacon of rebellion against the oppressive regime that sought to control every aspect of human thought and existence. And as the flames danced and leapt, Montag realized that this act of destruction was also a form of creation, a rebirth from the ashes of a society that had lost its way. The fire burned bright, a symbol of hope and defiance in the darkness.

What new perspectives would they offer? And most importantly, how would they change him? As he stood there, surrounded by the forbidden knowledge, Montag felt a surge of excitement and fear. He was on the brink of a profound transformation, one that would challenge everything he thought he knew. The journey ahead was uncertain, but one thing was clear: there was no turning back now.

Sin más demora, se agachó y recogió el libro, su piel sentada con el contacto frío del papel. Volvió a la puerta, mirando hacia atrás una última vez antes de desaparecer en la oscuridad, dejando atrás la vida que conocía y emprendiendo un viaje hacia lo desconocido. El libro, ahora bajo su almohada, prometía revelar secretos y desafiar su comprensión del mundo. He had to find a place where he could read, think, and perhaps, find others who shared his desire for a richer, more meaningful existence. en_results_raw: Montag felt his flesh jump and had the absurd thought that the girl's eyes were cameras hidden away behind all that black hair, sending off unseizable pictures of him, in burst of light, to be developed in some lab in the middle of the night. He looked away. "Well," he said, "it's not my problem." He felt her dark gaze still upon him and turned to see if that was so. She had gone. He stared after her a moment and then shifted his eyes to the sidewalk where her footprints in the dust were a promise that she had been there and perhaps would be there again, though no foot was in sight now. He looked back up at the beetle-colored sky and the falling drizzle of the special rain. He felt his hands, the kerosene nozzle in one of them, the igniter in the other. He felt his hands and thought, if you had a microscope to look at them closely you would see little ridges of pressure, little peaks of skin piled one on top of the other, in the faintest but irrefutable pattern, like aspens pressed together, the final and irrevocable design of a life formed by pressure on a sensitive skin that mapped out a way of going. And now, how suddenly, this girl who was so nervous, so jumpy, had gone and changed everything with a few words and a strange look. He felt his hands. He felt his arms. He felt his legs. He felt his mind. He felt his whole being flood with a terrible anger against the girl. Why wasn't she like the others? Why wasn't she normal? Why did she have to be like this? Why wasn't she like the ladies at the fire station? Well, hell! He couldn't stop here and think of her, think of her and how she made him feel. He couldn't stand still. He shook the nozzle in the air, his hands dancing above the river of kerosene. He felt the need to run, to race, to sweep her up in his arms and fly with her over the sleeping city, away from the fire, away from the falling night, away, anywhere, everywhere! He stood there, his boots melting little holes in the concrete, his hands trying to freeze each other, his face sunburned, his mind numbed with the effort of trying to understand what was happening to him. He felt his mouth dry and his throat choked with the kerosene fumes; he felt the need to plunge the burning fag-end of a cigarette into his own arm, to feel something, anything, to stop the silent, implacable sobbing of his heart. He looked up at the buildings around him and let the flood of their bright, luminous details drown his perception of everything else. He felt his hands go numb and drop the nozzle. He heard a hiss as the kerosene gushed over the pavement. He saw the blue and red neon signs across the street swim into his eyes. He heard a voice crying out, a voice that seemed to come from the sky, from the earth, from all things that lived and grew. The voice cried: "Montag, you idiot, you almost had it! Why did you stop?" He opened his eyes wide and looked around. The hissing was still in his ears. The pavement was still pouring the dark, familiar river of kerosene. The sun was still bright and high. The girl was still gone. The silence about him was complete. He felt his mouth move and heard a voice, small and thin, but desperately crying out the single word: "Millie!"

He remembered the title, the texture of the pages, the odd, musty smell of oldness that clung to the book. He remembered how his hand had hovered over it, how his eyes traced the letters on the spine, and how his mind had raced ahead of itself, trying to anticipate the story, the characters, the world that would open up to him if he could just touch the book and let it open and let the words bloom on the dark green of the page. "No," he repeated, but this time it was a whisper to himself. He felt a strange pull, a magnetic attraction toward that one book amidst the inferno. It was as if the book knew he was there, calling to him across the flames. Montag's heart pounded in his chest, a drumbeat of rebellion against the world he had known. He could almost hear the voices of the books, a chorus of lost knowledge and forbidden wisdom, urging him to reach out, to take the book into his hands and save it from the fire. The axe felt heavy in his grip, a symbol of his past, his role as a fireman. But the hose, still warm from the kerosene it had just sprayed, seemed to beckon him toward a different path, a path of discovery and understanding. Montag's resolve wavered. He took a step forward, his eyes fixed on "Green Darkness," and in that moment, the world he had known began to unravel. The fire roared around him, a living entity that seemed to hunger for more, more books to consume, more knowledge to erase. But within Montag, a different fire was kindled, a fire of curiosity and defiance. He reached out, his fingers brushing against the cool leather of the book's cover. The moment his skin made contact, it was as if a circuit was completed, a connection made to a vast, untapped reservoir of human experience and thought. The book seemed to hum with potential, with stories untold and ideas unexplored. Montag's grip tightened, and with a swift motion, he pulled the book from the shelf, cradling it against his chest. The firemen around him froze, their torches wavering as they stared at the man who had dared to defy the law. Montag felt a surge of power and fear, a heady mix of emotions that threatened to overwhelm him. But he held firm, the book pressed close to his heart, a beacon of hope in a world consumed by darkness. The firemen recovered, their torches reigniting with renewed fury, but Montag was already moving, his mind racing with possibilities. He had crossed a line, and there was no going back. The journey ahead would be fraught with danger and uncertainty, but Montag knew one thing for certain: he would read "Green Darkness," and he would learn its secrets. And perhaps, in doing so, he would find a way to light a candle in the darkness that threatened to engulf them all.

La revelación de esta verdad podría desencadenar un cambio radical en la sociedad, desafiando las estructuras de poder existentes y forzando a la humanidad a confrontar su pasado y su futuro con una nueva perspectiva. La respuesta a su pregunta no es simple, y la búsqueda de la verdad podría ser más peligrosa de lo que imagina.

He felt a strange detachment, as if he were watching a movie of someone else's life. The fire, once a symbol of his power and authority, now flickered uncertainly, reflecting the turmoil within him. The books, those forbidden objects of knowledge, lay strewn about, their pages ablaze, yet the words seemed to dance in the flames, teasing him with their elusive meanings. Montag's heart pounded in his chest, a drumbeat of realization and fear. He had always believed in the sanctity of his role, the righteousness of his cause. But as the fire consumed the last of the books, a question burned brighter than the flames: What had he truly been destroying? The past? Knowledge? Or perhaps, the very essence of humanity? Montag's world, once clear and defined, now blurred into a haze of doubt and curiosity. He stepped back, away from the inferno, his mind a tumult of conflicting thoughts. The fire hissed and crackled, a living thing that seemed to mock him, as if it knew a secret he was only beginning to suspect. Montag's hand, the one that had betrayed him, now trembled with the weight of its newfound independence. It was as if it had awakened from a long slumber, aware of the vastness of the world beyond the fireman's hose. And as the last embers died, leaving behind a smoldering ruin, Montag was left with a profound sense of loss and an insatiable hunger for the knowledge he had so recklessly destroyed. The journey he was about to embark on would be fraught with danger and uncertainty, but it was a path he could no longer ignore. His transformation had begun, not with a grand gesture, but with the simple, rebellious act of his own hand.

With a deep breath, he pressed his hand against it, feeling for the hidden mechanism that would reveal the concealed books. The wall resisted at first, but then, as if acknowledging Montag's newfound resolve, it gave way slightly. Montag's heart pounded in his chest as he pushed harder, and with a soft click, a section of the wall swung open, revealing a hidden alcove filled with books. The sight was both exhilarating and terrifying. Here, in this secret chamber, were the forbidden fruits of knowledge that Montag had been taught to fear and destroy. Yet, now, they beckoned to him, promising enlightenment and understanding. Montag stepped forward, his hands trembling as he reached out to touch the first book. The texture of the cover was rough under his fingers, a stark contrast to the smooth, sterile surfaces of his world. He pulled a book from the shelf and opened it, the pages crackling with age. The words on the page seemed to leap out at him, eager to be read, to impart their wisdom. Montag's mind raced with questions and possibilities. What truths lay within these pages? What new perspectives would they offer? And most importantly, how would they change him? As he stood there, surrounded by the forbidden knowledge, Montag felt a surge of excitement and fear. He was on the brink of a profound transformation, one that would challenge everything he thought he knew. The journey ahead was uncertain, but one thing was clear: there was no turning back now.

en_results_raw: Montag stood with the flame-thrower in his limp hands, great islands of perspiration drenching his armpits, his face smeared with soot and ash. The house before him, once a sanctuary of books and secrets, now lay in ruins, its walls collapsing under the relentless assault of the fire. The acrid smell of burning paper and wood filled his nostrils, a scent he had grown all too familiar with over the years. As the last embers flickered and died, Montag felt a profound sense of emptiness wash over him. The destruction he had wrought was not just on the physical structure before him, but on the very essence of knowledge and thought it once contained. He realized, with a sinking heart, that he had been complicit in the obliteration of culture and intellect, tools that humanity desperately needed to navigate the complexities of their world. The silence that followed the fire's demise was deafening, a stark contrast to the roaring flames that had just subsided. Montag's mind raced with questions and doubts, his previous convictions now seeming hollow and misguided. The realization that he had been part of a system designed to suppress individual thought and creativity was a bitter pill to swallow. As he stood amidst the smoldering ruins, Montag knew that his life would never be the same. The path forward was unclear, but one thing was certain: he could no longer continue down the destructive path he had been on. The journey ahead would be fraught with challenges and dangers, but it was a path he had to walk if he was to find redemption and meaning. The fight against the oppressive regime and its destructive policies had just begun, and Montag was determined to play his part, no matter the cost. This moment, standing amidst the ashes of his past, marked the beginning of his transformation from a tool of destruction to a champion of enlightenment and freedom.

The world he knew was crumbling, and with each step, he felt the pull towards a new horizon, one filled with the potential for change and enlightenment. He had to find a place where he could read, think, and perhaps, find others who shared his desire for a richer, more meaningful existence. He had crossed a line from which there was no turning back. The city was a furnace, and he was now the kindling. He needed to think, to plan, to escape. But first, he had to get past the Hound. Montag's mind raced, searching for a solution. He knew the Hound relied on scent, and he had to eliminate his trail. He considered the flamethrower strapped to his back, a tool of his trade, now a potential weapon against his pursuers. With a swift motion, he detached the device and turned it towards the Hound. The irony was not lost on him; using fire to escape the very firemen he once was. The Hound's sensors whirred, confused by the sudden influx of heat and smoke. Montag seized this moment of distraction. He sprinted away, his boots pounding against the pavement, the adrenaline fueling his escape. Behind him, he could hear the Hound's frustrated growls, its mechanical nature unable to adapt quickly enough to this unexpected turn of events. Montag knew he couldn't outrun the Hound forever, but he had bought himself precious moments. He needed to find Faber, the professor who had become his unlikely mentor, the man who could help him make sense of the books and the chaos unfolding around him. The city was a labyrinth, but Montag was desperate, and desperation lent him speed and cunning. He ducked into alleys, leaped over obstacles, and disappeared into the maze of streets, his mind focused on one goal: survival and the hope of a future where books and thought were not feared but cherished.

I wanted to do things that would make people cry when I was gone. Not because I was dead, but because I would no longer be around to do those things. I wanted to leave the world a little better than I found it, just like my grandfather did. So, I became a teacher. I teach kids to think, to question, to dream. Con cada palabra pronunciada bajo su aliento, sentía cómo se desintegraba la cadena que lo ataba a una vida que no era realmente suya. Era un acto de autodeterminación, un grito silencioso pero potente contra la opresión invisible. La oscuridad le ofrecía un escenario perfecto para meditar sobre el futuro incierto que se avecinaba, un futuro lleno de riesgos, pero también de posibilidades infinitas. Granger cerró los ojos, permitiéndole a su mente viajar libremente, preparándose para lo que vendría. La mañana traería cambios, cambios que quizás alteraran su mundo para siempre, pero él estaba dispuesto a enfrentarlos, ya que ahora tenía una visión clara de lo que quería alcanzar. La libertad, la verdadera libertad, era lo único que valía la pena luchar por.

tr_second_half: yaşlar akarak, Granger ayağa kalktı. Ayaklarını sürüyerek ırmağın akıntısına bakmak için yürüdü.

Bu zorlu anı, onun dayanıklılığını ve kararlılığını sınırlamadan gösterdi; her şeyi yaparken, huzur ve sakinlik arayışında kalmayı unutamadı.

en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”
en_results_raw: Granger's words hung heavy in the air, a somber reminder of the weight of their mission. As they continued upstream, the landscape transformed from the familiar to the alien. The river, once a ribbon of life, now seemed a vein of sorrow, threading through a land scarred by neglect and time. The group moved in silence, each lost in their own thoughts, grappling with the enormity of their task and the responsibility it entailed.

Proseguimos escupiendo sobre las tumbas de todos los pobres que habían muerto antes que nosotros. Durante la próxima semana, el próximo mes y el próximo año
es_second_half: vamos a conocer a mucha gente solitaria. Y cuando nos pregunten lo que hacemos, podemos decir: «Estamos recordando.» Ahí es donde venceremos a la larga. Y, algún día, recordaremos tanto, que construiremos la mayor pala mecánica de la Historia, con la que excavaremos la sepultura mayor de todos los tiempos, donde meteremos la guerra y la enterraremos. Vamos, ahora. Ante todo, deberemos construir una fábrica de espejos, y durante el próximo año, sólo fabricaremos espejos y nos miraremos prolongadamente en ellos.
es_results_raw: George continuó, su voz cargada de una determinación casi tangible. "Durante la próxima semana, el próximo mes y el próximo año, intentaremos ser mejores. Intentaremos recordar que cada acción cuenta, que cada palabra tiene peso, y que cada pensamiento puede cambiar el curso de nuestro destino. No podemos permitirnos caer en la arrogancia de creer que somos más importantes que el mundo que nos rodea.
